JavaScript Weekly

npmx: A New npm Registry Package Browser â€” A smooth, fast way to browse packages on the official npm registry. Itâ€™s certainly fast, smooth, and you see more info up front and center - check out the axios page for example. â€œWeâ€™re not replacing the npm registry, but instead providing an elevated developer experience through a fast, modernÂ UI.â€

npmx

ğŸ’¡ A particularly nifty feature is the ability to compare packages quickly, in areas like size, dependencies, module format, license,Â etc.

The Most Loved JavaScript Course Year AfterÂ Year â€” JavaScript: The Hard Parts is rated 4.92 on average by thousands of developers. Build real mental models for how JavaScript works, from execution context and closures to async behavior and modern languageÂ features.

Frontend Masters sponsor

ğŸ“ŠÂ The State of JS 2025 Survey Results â€” The results of the annual survey are here, compiling the opinions of over 12,000 JavaScript developers into a flurry of charts in areas as diverse as language pain points, frontend framework choices, build tool usage, how much of their code is AI generated, and what non-JS/TS languages theyÂ use.

Devographics

ESLint v10.0.0 Released â€” This long-awaited milestone completes the removal of the legacy eslintrc config system, introduces a new config lookup algorithm that starts from the linted file (great for monorepos), adds JSX reference tracking to fix scope analysis issues, andÂ more.

ESLint Team

IN BRIEF:

  • webpack shares its 2026 roadmap. Topics include support for a universal target to compile code to run on numerous runtimes, building TypeScript without loaders, CSS modules without plugins, andÂ more.

  • VoidZero shares its January 2026 recap covering updates to Oxlint, Oxfmt, Vitest, andÂ more.

  • Deno Deploy is now GA as a platform for easily deploying JS/TS apps to the Web. There's also a 45 minute video where Ryan Dahl shows itÂ off.

  • ğŸ¤¯ Promethee provides UEFI bindings for JavaScript. Write a UEFI bootloader in JavaScript instead of C?Â Yep.

RELEASES:

  • ğŸ¤– Transformers.js v4 Preview â€“ Run ML models in the browser on top of a new WebGPUÂ runtime.

  • Bun v1.3.9 â€“ Run multiple package.json scripts concurrently/sequentially with --parallel/--sequential, faster Bun.markdown.react(), regexps get a SIMD boost, andÂ more.

  • Ink 6.7 â€“ Build rich terminal apps with React. v6.7 adds concurrent rendering and synchronized updates (lessÂ flicker!)

  • Ember 6.10 â€“ Cleanups and modernization for the stable, battle-testedÂ framework.

ğŸ“–Â  Articles and Videos

Itâ€™s About to Get a Lot Easier For Your JavaScript to Clean Up AfterÂ Itself â€” A fun technical exploration of Symbol.dispose and using, two new features thatâ€™ll ease many headaches around cleaning up after yourself: closing connections, freeing resources, etc. Just watch out for theÂ Muppetsâ€¦

Mat Marquis

â–¶Â Â Evan You on Vite, Rust and the Future of JSÂ Tooling â€” The Vue.js creator joined the Better Stack podcast to discuss his path from building Vite to founding VoidZero and developing a Rust-based JS toolchain.

Evan You and Better Stack

Debugging a Next.js Production Issue with Sentry Logs, Not JustÂ Errors â€” Lessons from a Next.js production debugging session where understanding behavior mattered more than stackÂ traces.

Sentry sponsor

ğŸ¤–Â Debugging React with AI: Can It Replace an Experienced Developer? â€” Nadia rigged up an app laced with subtle bugs, unleashed Claude on it, andâ€¦ watched it fail toÂ impress.

Nadia Makarevich

Shovel.js: What If Your Server Were Just a ServiceÂ Worker? â€” A full-stack framework and meta-framework built around the Service Worker model, using Web APIs wherever possible to provide a consistent server surface across Node, Bun, and edge runtimes.

Brian Kim

VerifyFetch: Fetch Large Files with Resume and VerificationÂ Features â€” Imagine fetch but with the ability to resume downloads, check you downloaded what you meant to download, and fail fast on any corruption. GitHubÂ repo.

Hamza Ezzaydia

Teach Your AI Coding Agent How to Implement ClerkÂ Authentication â€” One command installs Clerk Skills for Claude Code, Cursor, Copilot, and more. Your agent learns auth so you shipÂ faster.

Clerk sponsor

ğŸ”Â OTPAuth: One-Time Password (HOTP/TOTP) Library â€” Node, Deno, Bun and browser library to generate and validate TOTP and HOTP one-time passwords used in two-factorÂ auth.

Shaka Project

  • Meriyah 7.1 â€“ Long-standing 100% compliant (ES2024), self-hosted JavaScript parser which you can play withÂ here.

  • React Grab 1.0 â€“ Tool for selecting components in the browser to feed to agents toÂ edit.

  • Downshift 9.3 â€“ Primitives to build WAI-ARIA compliant React autocomplete, combobox & select dropdownÂ components.

  • VuePDF 2.0 â€“ Render PDFs in Vue 3Â apps.

  • Lume 3.2 â€“ Static site generator forÂ Deno.

ğŸ‰Notion, Dropbox, Wiz, and LaunchDarkly have switched to Meticulous for frontend tests that provide near-exhaustive coverage with zero developer effort. Find outÂ why.

ğŸ“¸ Add robust 1D/2D barcode scanning to your web app with STRICH. Easy integration, simple pricing. Free trial and demo appÂ available.

  • â­ Shades of Halftone is Maxime Heckel's grand tour of pixelation, dithering, and the creation of GLSL-powered halftone effects with React Three Fiber. An aesthetic increasingly popular in modern web design and digital art.

item.description:
ã€

#â€‹771 â€” February 3, 2026

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Four Heavyweights Drop Updates

Four stalwarts of the JavaScript ecosystem all shipped notable releases this week, and odds are you're using at least one of them:

  • Gatsby v5.16 proves Gatsby, once considered neck-and-neck with Next.js in the React world, is not 'dead'. The headline feature is React 19Â support.

  • Babel 7 just shipped its final release. "After years in the making, Babel 8 is finally ready," in release candidate form, atÂ least.

  • Rspress 2.0 is a major release for the high-performance Rust-powered, but JavaScript-facing, static siteÂ generator.

  • Lodash 4.17.23 sounds minor, but it's a 'security reset' for the still heavily used utility library and is designed to provide a base for a longerÂ future.

Only Fools Write Tests â€” Modern engineering teams like Notion, Dropbox, Wiz, and LaunchDarkly use Meticulous to maintain E2E UI tests that cover every edge case of your webÂ app.

Meticulous sponsor

ğŸ¦€Â OpenClaw: The Runaway AI Assistant â€” An intense week for a new open source TypeScript project: 150k stars on GitHub, hordes buying Mac Minis to run it, two rebrands (it was originally Clawdbot), and an ecosystem of projects the agents use autonomously (e.g. an entire social network). Another example of TypeScript at the heart of the AIÂ boom.

Peter Steinberger

IN BRIEF:

  • The popular JSBin collaborative JavaScript pastebin went down for a few days and Remy Sharp shares the war story of what happened.

  • ğŸ”’ The OpenJS Foundation has shared an annual report covering its efforts in securing the JSÂ ecosystem.

  • Angular is changing components' default change detection strategy.

  • Both Astro and Svelte have shared monthly roundups of what'sÂ new.

RELEASES:

  • Node.js v25.6.0 (Current) â€“ async_hooks can now skip Promise hooks to reduce overhead. Plus, URL parsing now supports UnicodeÂ 17.

  • jQuery UI 1.14.2 â€“ The legacy UI library gets its first update in over a year and now works with jQueryÂ 4.0.

  • Bun v1.3.8 â€“ Say hello to native MarkdownÂ parsing.

  • Astro 5.17, ESLint 10.0.0-rc2, tRPC v11.9.0, Lexical 0.40.0, Reka UI 2.8 (formerly RadixÂ Vue)

ğŸ“–Â  Articles and Videos

â‰ï¸Â How Not to Parse Numbers in JavaScript â€” Why use a proper locale-aware API to parse numbers when you can hand-roll a maze of string splits, separator swaps, and implicit type coercions that silently break on edgeÂ cases?

Remy Porter (The Daily WTF)

ğŸ“‰Â Node.js 16 to 25 Benchmarked Version-by-Version â€” The jumps in performance in various areas are striking (with Node 25, especially), with other areas getting more modestÂ gains.

RepoFlow

A Practical Checklist for B2B Enterprise Readiness â€” Measure gaps in auth, admin UX, security, monitoring, and architecture for landing enterprise customers. DownloadÂ today!

Descope sponsor

Explicit Resource Management in JavaScript â€” You can use using for deterministic cleanup, calling Symbol.dispose/asyncDispose at scope exit without try/finally. A small fix for leaks and forgotten teardowns in streams, observers, locks, and similarÂ APIs.

Matt Smith

The History of C# and TypeScript with Anders Hejlsberg â€” GitHub interviewed the creator of both C# and TypeScript about his career, why TypeScript was created in the first place, some internal Microsoft politics, as well as the ongoing Go port of the TypeScriptÂ compiler. There's a video of the full interview, as well as 'seven learnings' boiled down in writtenÂ form.

GitHub

ğŸ“„ My Opinionated ESLint Setup for Vue Projects â€“ Packed with examples to pick and chooseÂ from. Alexander Opalic

ğŸ“„ A Scroll-Revealed WebGL Gallery with GSAP, Three.js, Astro and Barba.js â€“ Striking visual image reveal effect with a liveÂ demo. Chakib Mazouni

ğŸ“„ Predicting Math.random() in Firefox Using Z3 SMT-Solver Dennis Yurichev

ğŸ¤ Securing npm is Table Stakes Nicholas C. Zakas (Changelog Podcast)

ğŸ“„ Building a Simple RSS Aggregator with Astro Raymond Camden

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Heat.js 5.0: A Flexible Heat Map Rendering Solution â€” Generate customized interactive heatmaps (think GitHub contributions graph), or render heatmaps as lines and bar charts. The site is packed with demos to enjoy. GitHubÂ repo.

William Troup

Building an MCP Server? Don't Roll Your Own Auth â€” WorkOS AuthKit handles OAuth 2.1 flows so your MCP server just verifies tokens. Control which tools AI agentsÂ access.

WorkOS sponsor

ğŸ•’Â Croner 10.0: Cron-Style Triggers and Evaluation â€” Trigger functions on any cron schedule using cron syntax. It can also evaluate cron expressions to give you a list of upcoming times. v10.0 brings full OCPS (Open Cron Pattern Specification) 1.4 compliance and even more schedulingÂ options.

Hexagon

ğŸ—“ï¸Â DayFlow: A Full Calendar Component for React â€” A React-only feature-rich calendar component with drag-and-drop, multiple views, and all the usual GCal-style richness. Its infinite scrolling feature is nifty. GitHubÂ repo.

DayFlow Contributors

Tsonic: A TypeScript to C# Transpiler â€” The idea is for creating native executables that run on .NET. Iâ€™ve not tested it as Iâ€™m not in that ecosystem but itâ€™s an interestingÂ idea.

Jeswin

  • ğŸ“„ EmbedPDF 2.4 â€“ Framework-agnostic JavaScript PDF viewer. (Demo.)

  • JavaScriptKit v0.40 â€“ Swift framework for interacting with JS viaÂ WASM.

  • StackBlur.js 3.0 â€“ Long-standing Gaussian blur library; now usingÂ ESM.

  • Knip 5.83 â€“ Finds and fixes unused files, dependencies andÂ exports.

  • ğŸ“„ jsPDF 4.1 â€“ Generate PDFs directly in JavaScript. (Demo.)

  • qrcode.vue 3.8 â€“ Vue.js component to generate QRÂ codes.

  • focus-trap 8.0 â€“ Trap focus within a DOM node. (Demo.)

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere in the ecosystem

Some other interesting tidbits in the broader landscape:

  • GitHub is exploring solutions to tackle low-quality contributions, which could include giving you the option to disable PRs entirely or at least restrict them to collaborators. Got opinions? Join theÂ discussion.

  • How to throttle individual network requests in Chrome, rather than at a global level. Ideal for testing what happens when your dependencies load veryÂ slooooooowwwwwly....

  • ğŸ¤– OpenAI has released a desktop version of its agentic-coding Codex app. macOS only for now, though someone used Codex to port itself to Linux..Â ğŸ˜‚

  • âš ï¸ If you're a Windows user using the popular Notepad++ editor, you might want to double check your install as the project suffered a suspected state-sponsored hijack inÂ 2025.

  • svelteesp32 is a curious project for embedding Svelte, React, Angular or Vue frontends into ESP32 microcontrollerÂ apps.

ã€

#â€‹770 â€” January 27, 2026

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Introducing LibPDF: PDF Parsing and Generation from TypeScript â€” LibPDF bills itself as â€˜the PDF library TypeScript deservesâ€™ and supports parsing, modifying, signing and generating PDFs with a modern API in Node, Bun, and the browser. GitHubÂ repo.

Documenso

JavaScript Frameworks â€“ Heading into 2026 â€” The creator of SolidJS knows more than a thing or two about JS frameworks and has written an annual review of the scene for the past few years. Here, he picks on four areas of evolution, and says itâ€™s â€œan incredibly exciting time to be working on JavaScriptÂ frameworks.â€

Ryan Carniato

Still Writing Tests Manually? â€” Notion, Dropbox, Wiz, and LaunchDarkly have found a new testing paradigm - and they can't imagine working without it. Built by ex-Palantir engineers, Meticulous autonomously creates a continuously evolving suite of E2E UI tests that delivers near-exhaustive coverage with zero developerÂ effort.

ã€

#â€‹769 â€” January 20, 2026

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

jQuery 4.0 Released â€” 20 years on from its original release, the ever-popular (in terms of actual usage) library reaches 4.0 with a migration to ES modules (compatible with modern build tools) along with dropping support for IE 10 and older. With jQuery being a popular guest in our newsletters in the early years, itâ€™s fantastic to see it pop back for a quickÂ visit.
